file.title: Document Object Model (DOM)
file.bullet: There are a variety of ways to query the DOM for elements.
We will cover methods for retrieving elements by id, class, or tag name.
We will also cover the direct access of form inputs.
When you want to retrieve an individual HTML element, it is very easy to do so by accessing it by its id with the document.getElementById() method.
In the example above, the id btnToClick is on a button element. When we call document.getElementById() with that id, we get back the button element.
If an element with the specified id is not found, null will be returned by the document.getElementById() method.

Elements are also often located by class.

To access HTML elements by class, use the document.getElementsByClassName() method.
document.getElementsByClassName() returns an HTML element collection (NodeList) of elements.
NoteElements, plural, in the method name; not Element, singular. Unlike document.getElementById(),

file.bullet: Elements may also be located by html Tag.

To access HTML elements by their tag, use the document.getElementsByTagName() method.
document.getElementsByTagName() returns an HTML element collection (NodeList) of elements.

Example:
Here we use the getElementsByTagName to get all the elements of a single class.

ul.li: Create a page with a heading tag, and three paragraph tags.
Use document.getElementsByTagName('p') to get all the paragraphs tags from the page.
Write their innerHTML text to the console log.

file.bullet: Some elements, like form inputs, can be accessed directly by name through special properties on the document object.
